title: In movies, is there anyone talking on the phone when an actor does a phone scene? - Quora

response.answer_text: It really depends. Many times, if it’s a short phone call, then no. I mean, they’re actors, they should be able to act a phone call. However, some directors and actors love having someone on the other end to play off of. If they’re not on the phone, then they’re off camera giving the actor the “voice” from the other end of the line. Then there’s the random film I got to work on called “Columbus Day” with Val Kilmer, Marg Helgenberger, Wilmer Valderrama and others. Because so much of the film takes place over phone calls, the director definitely wanted working phones and voices on the other end for the actors to play off of. I had known the Casting Director for a while and he called and asked if I’d be interested. Good pay, working with a new director and some good names, and I don’t have to memorize anything? Sure! It was a blast because they did have working phones, and I got to portray a number of characters on the other end of the line (including my take on Val and Wilmer). It was a unique situation, to be sure, but to answer your question: Sometimes they do. And even if it doesn’t include screen-time, it can still be pretty fun!

Some years ago, I was a guest at Armageddon Con in New Zealand. One of the other guests was the voice actor Roger L. Jackson. Roger was amazing, and I had the pleasure of doing a panel with him. He is, perhaps, best known for voicing Ghostface in the “Scream” horror franchise. Roger told me (and a room full of excited fans) that he had originally been cast as a placeholder voice, as the director really wanted the actors to be talking to an actual person when they were supposed to be on the phone with the homicidal maniac. As it turned out, Roger creeped out the lead actresses so much, he went on to be used as the actual voice of Ghostface. If you’ve ever heard him, you’ll understand why. So that’s at least one example of a movie wherein an actor actually was on the phone during the story’s phone calls.
